channel.title: Levinson news clips: TV reviews
channel.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
channel.description: 5-minute reviews of tv and movies, and occasional brief analyses of media news and controversies: I've been interviewed more than 500 times on radio and television in the United States, Canada, England, Italy and Australia including ABC's "NightLine", "CBS Evening News with Dan Rather", PBS' "The NewsHour with Jim Lehrer", "The O'Reilly Factor", "Scarborough Country", "Jesse Ventura's America", "The Big Story with John Gibson", ABC's "World News Now", "Daybreak", "Your World with Neil Cavuto", PBS, CNN, Fox News, MSNBC, CNBC, the History Channel, "Today in New York", "Good Day New York", WNBC-TV, WCBS-TV, WB-11, "Inside Edition", AP Radio, CBS Radio Network News, Bloomberg Radio, CNN Radio, NPR's "Talk of the Nation", "Morning Edition", "The Diane Rehm Show", "On the Media", "The Connection","on Point", "Public Interest (The Kojo Nnamdi Show)", "Odyssey", "Tech Nation", "New York and Company", and many local NPR affiliates and local radio and tv, and the BBC's "NewsNight" and "Thinking Allowed" and he has been quoted frequently in the New York Times, USA Today, Washington Post, Los Angeles Times, Wall Street Journal, Smithsonian Magazine, U.S. News and World Report, Forbes, Christian Science Monitor, New York Daily News, New York Post, Newsday, Boston Globe, San Francisco Chronicle, Hollywood Reporter, Daily Variety, Billboard, Toronto Star, Montreal Gazette, Atlanta Journal-Constitution, Houston Chronicle, Philadelphia Inquirer, Miami Herald, Newark Star-Ledger, Orlando Sentinel, Cleveland Plain-Dealer, Detroit News, Dallas Morning News, the Cape Cod Times, Associated Press, Reuters, UPI, Scripps-Howard, and dozens of other major newspapers, magazines, and news services. On this podcast you'll get my thoughts on major media events as soon as they happen - and reviews of brand new movies and tv shows -in audio clips, usually a few minutes long. Available free to radio producers and podcasters to use on their shows, and to print journalists to quote in their stories. Attribution should be given to Paul Levinson, Professor of Communication, Fordham University.
channel.itunes:subtitle: reviews of current, excellent TV shows
channel.itunes:summary: audio clips by a national/international media commentator - reviews and analyses - available to radio producers, podcasters, and print journalists
channel.itunes:keywords: news, radio, clips, press, media, reviews, television, movies

item.title: NCIS 8.22: "I'd Rather Have a Lead"
item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
item.description:
Gibbs quips "I'd rather have a lead" than a pre-cog crime unit from Minority Report in NCIS 8.22, which features Gibbs and DiNozzo ten years ago, and leaves us with three mysteries in the present: (1) whose blue opened MTAC, (2) who is the NCIS team member in the coroner's wagon next week, and (3) who is the port-to-port killer?

 

blog post review:  NCIS 2.22: "I'd Rather Have a Lead"

item.title: Boardwalk Empire 1.10: Arnold Rothstein, Media Theorist
item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
item.description:
This superb episode 1.10 of Boardwalk Empire features a bar mitzvah attended by Al Capone, a hot scene with repressed Federal agent Alden, and Arnold Rothstein talking media theory as he had read McLuhan's Understanding Media or my The Soft Edge: A Natural History and Future of the Information Revolution.  This series is one of the best ever on HBO, which is to say, ever on television.

 

blog post review: Boardwalk Empire 1.10: Arnold Rothstein, Media Theorist

item.title: Preliminary Predictions for Lost Finale
item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
item.description:
A first crack at specific predictions about how Lost will end.  My predictions center around the expectation that the "better" LA alternate reality will collapse into the true, original island reality.  This podcast explores why LA is "better," how the collapse will occur, and what consequences.

 

blog post review:  Preliminary Predictions for Lost Finale

item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson

item.title: Treme!
item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
item.description:
David Simon's Treme premiered on HBO last night.  Simon's work was last seen in The Wire, one of the best shows ever on television.  Treme lives up to its maker's reputation, with great acting, music, local flavor as befits a story that unfolds in New Orleans, 3 months after Katrina.

 

blog post review:  Treme

 

listen to Louis Prima's Buona Sera , featured in the Treme premiere

item.title: Bones 100: Two Kisses and One Wild Relationship
item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
item.description:
Bones 100 gives us Bones and Booth kissing twice - once in the past, during their first case, and once right now - and guess what impact that has on their relationship?  A superb episode with all sorts of delightful details.

 

blog post review:  Bones 100: Two Deep Kisses and One Wild Relationship

item.title: Lost 6.11: Desmond Starts Sewing Together the Two Realities
item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
item.description:
A brilliantly satisfying Lost 6.11, in which Desmond in better LA - with Charlie and Daniel's help - finally starts sewing the two torn-apart realities back together...

 

 

blog post:  Lost 6.11: The Reunion of Two Realities Begins

item.title: FlashForward 1.14: Somalia, LA, Fate Irresistible and Not
item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
item.description:
One of the best - maybe the best - episode (1.14) of FlashForward so far, which shows the flashforwards irresistibly on their way to come true, in Somalia and LA, with one big exception.   And there's D. Gibbons apparently talking across time...

 

blog post review:  FlashForward 1.14:  Somalia, LA, Fate Resistible and Irresistible

item.title: Moral Dilemma and Great Writing in 24.8.14
item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
item.description:

item.title: Caprica 1.8: The Metaphysics of Flesh
item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
item.description:
Caprica continues as the most philosophically fascinating science fiction currently on television, with Episode 1.8, which delves into the relationship of intelligence and life in the real vs. virtual world.

 

blog post review:  Caprica 1.8: The Metaphysics of Flesh

 

books referred to in this podcast:

Phenomenology of Perception by Maurice Merleau-Ponty

Mind at Large: Knowing in the Technological Age by Paul Levinson

item.title: FlashForward 1.12: Simon's Story
item.itunes:author: Paul Levinson
item.description:
